description: A stunning Gothic Revival cathedral built between 1898-1903, originally commissioned as a Roman Catholic church by the wealthy Zubalashvili brothers and designed by Polish architect Aleksander Rogojski. After serving as a Soviet physics laboratory for decades, it was transferred to the Georgian Orthodox Church in 1989 and consecrated by Patriarch Elijah II. Now the principal Georgian Orthodox cathedral in Batumi and seat of the bishop of Batumi and Lazeti, featuring magnificent stained glass, pointed arches, twin spires, and ornate iconostasis.

vibe: Sacred, peaceful, and architecturally magnificent. The Gothic Revival grandeur creates an atmosphere of reverence enhanced by Orthodox liturgical traditions. The space feels both European and distinctly Georgian - a unique fusion of Catholic architectural heritage and Orthodox spiritual practice. Natural light filtering through stained glass creates an ethereal quality, while the gilded iconostasis adds warmth and color. Despite being a tourist attraction, it maintains authentic functionality as a working cathedral, creating an atmosphere of living faith rather than museum preservation.
